document.text: Winchester.Formal organization of a chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution is to be effected this week, it was announced by Miss Katherine R. Glass, organizing regent. The preliminary work has occupied most of a year, during which pros pective members have complied with membership requirements. Lynchburg.The City Council has declined to amend the city code so as to permit the operation, of billiard and pool rooms on second floors and in basements. The present ordinance re quires these places to be where they may be seen at all times by the police. The police authorities strenuously ob jected to the code being amended. FredericksburgThe office of road commissioner in Spotsylvania county is now vacant, caused by the resigna- j tlon of Cbmmissioner Fred Nusey. The Board of Supervisors will call a meet ing for the purpose of nominating the candidate for the position, who must be approved by the State Highway Commission. . Staunton.That the deaths of the Rev. Thomas Howell, of Waynesboro, and Christopher Pleasants, of Basic, both of whom were killed by automo biles, were unfortunate and distress ing accidents wais the opinion of the grand jury which, in a report to the Circuit Court, exonerated Alex Bush and Jack Van Lear, drivers of the cars, from any criminal liability. Lynchburg.S. G. Proffitt, the new United States marshal for the -West ern District of Virginia, will, it is learned here, move his headquarters and office to Roanoke during the Jan uary term of the district court here. Because of the duties of the office con nected with frequent terms of court since Mr. Proffitt entered upon the discharge of the duties of his office he has been unable to snake the change. Fredericksburg.Former State Sen ator R. C. L. Moncure, of -Stafford county, is being urged by his friends for the seat in the - State Industrial Comanislon, now held by Charles A. McHugh, of Roanoke. Mr. Moncure was the collector of internal revenue for this Federal district under the Wil son administration. The salary of a member of the State Industrial Com mission is 4,000 per year. Danville.Frank Robertson, of this city, indicted in the County Circuit Court on the charge of violating the Mapp act, was given his unconditional release when it was shown that, while officers had found a quantity of liquor in Robertsons house, they did not have a .search warrant. Judge A. M. Aiken ruled that evidence secured in this way could not be introduced against tne accused, whereupon the Commonwealths case collapsed. Norfolk.A proposal to establish a fair-price commission for the city mar ket and to clothe it w-ith full power to enforce its decisions, may be puti forward as a possible solution of one phase of Norfolks cost of living prob- lem as a result of the Inquiry now in progress. A recommendation Covering this point will probably be included in the report of the food committee which has been making a sweeping investiga tion into .prices on he market during the course of Its labors. Winchester.Mrs. Marguerite E. Harrison, -speaking under auspices of the Handley Foundation, graphically pictured her experiences while a pris oner of Soviets in Russia for many months. Her lecture was given in Market Street Methodist Episcopal Church, and She was introduced by R. Gray Williams, president of the hoard of Handley trustees. Mrs. Harrisons first appearance on the. lecture plat form was here, following her return from Germany some months after sign ing of the armistice. Lynchburg.W. C. Sale, clerk in charge of the postal car on Norfolk and Western Railway trains 15 and 16, Norfolk to Columbus, who lives in Nor folk, was painfully shot here When the regulation .45 caliber revolver the clerks are required to carry, slipped from his hand as he was attempting to put it in the holster. The steel jacket bullet struck Mr. Sale about eight inches below the left thigh and ranged in a zig-zag course around his hip. An X-ray negative, which was developed this forenoon, disclosed the fact that the bullet missed the thigh and hip hones and its location was re vealed, making its removal possible by a slight operation. Fredericksburg.  The historic Spottswood Inn, at Spotsylvania Court house, ten miles from this city, has been purchased by Mrs. Willie Rhoades Walter, of -that county, from Frederick W. Coleman, of this city. The property consisted of the hotel, outbuildings and ninety-four acres of land. Mrs. Waller has taken posses sion of the property and will remodel the Inn. This property is one of the historic landmarks of Spotsylvania county. It was used by General Robert E. Lee as headquarters daring the battle of Spotsylvania Courthouse and Bloddy Angle. Lynchburg.City Manager, Beck, in connection with the preparation for the city budget for 1922 here, has given the City Council a tentative -idea of what he has in mind to recommend for the .coming year, which would in clude along with general street im provements, the building of an athletic stadium at Thirteenth and Court streets on city owned property con version of the prfsent city market and city auditorium Into a city hall. This work, and the two new school buildings already authorized at a cost of 300,000.

document.text: While Charles Zetty was fishing in the Shenandoah River his hook caught In a womans clothing. When the dead body was brought to the surface it proved to be that of Mrs. Bessie Lloyd, wife of Thomas Lloyd, a Norfolk and Western Railway man, of Shenandoah City. Mrs. Lloyd was seen last Sun day night. Despondent from domestic troubles she had been threatening to drown herself and late on Sunday night, it is evident, she stole away to the river and jumped in. She was born In Scotland fifty years ago.

document.text: Walter V. Mann, 715, died at has home at 440 P. M. Thursday after a long illness. Born in Appomattox County, Dec. 2, 1881, he was the son of the late Henry and Fannie Mann Mann. He was twice married, first to Lizzie B. Hendrick, who died in 1942, and he is survived by his wife, Mary Thomas Mann. He was a retired employee of Norfolk and Western Railway, hav ing worked with the railway for 43 years. He was a member o f the Memorial Methodist Church. _ .Surviving, in addition to his wife are three daughters, Mrs. Sallie Sharp, Appomattox Mrs. Coy Wooten and Mrs. Mamie Capelone- gta, Brooklyn, N. Y. a son, B. E Mann, Appomattox four sisters, Mrs. D. B. Johnson, Powhatan Mrs. West Johnson, Miss Betty Mann, and Mrs. R. W. Aimrid, Appomat- tox 13 grandchildren, and four, great grandbhildrdnu FUneral services yvere held. Feb. Governor 23 in Robinson. Funeral Chapel, with the Rev. L. H. Richcreek and Dr. Carl A. Collins Jr. conducting the rites. A trio of Mr. and . Mrs. Franklin Vaughan and John Hall sang for the services. Miss Peggy Godlsey accompanied at, the organ. Pallbearers were Jimmie Johnson, Hudson. Seale, Robert Almond, Ray mond Hall, Raymond E. Mann and J. W. Watson. Interment was in Liberty Cemetery.

document.text: W. Twyman Coleman, proprietor of Colemans Feed and Seed Store here, has announced purchase of the lots from the Norfolk and Western Railway across from Hotel Appomat tox on Main Street. He plana to begin work very shortly on a new feed store on this site. The pro posed building will be 62 by 140 feet, a one story cinder block build ing, and will include a 12 x 20 base ment.

document.text: w t HEN you see a Norfolk and Western  X  passenger train flash by, or watch one YY of the railroads fast freight trains speeding through your county, you think of people traveling, or the movement of goods- You take the railroad for granted you ac cept its efficient and dependable transporta tion service as a commonplace of modern civil ization. But the railroad is more than a transpor tation agency it does more than carry you and your neighbors safely from one place to an other, transport your crops and livestock to market, and bring the necessities and luxuries of life to you. It is a citizen of, and one of the largest taxpayers in, your county. It is one of the chief contributors toward the operation and upkeep of county and district schools, the construction and maintenance of county roads, and the operation of county government. In making up their annual budgets, members of the school boards, road supervisors and gov ernment officials count heavily on this source of revenue, for railroad taxes, which are paid promptly, constitute a largeand necessary- part of their total funds. v , The Norfolk and Western Railway is such a taxpayer and citizen of Appomattox -County. Consider these facts The total county taxes collected from all sources during 1930 by your county treasurer, amounted to 66,469.63. Of this amount the N.  W. the only railroad serving the county paid 18,931.21, or 28.48 per cent of the total collections. Of the total railroad taxes, 53.62 per cent, or 10,149.79 was used in the operation of your county and district schools 18.15 per cent, or 3,436.58 was used for the construction and maintenance of your .county roads and 28-23 per cent, or 5,344.84 was used in the operation of your

document.text: W ingina. The inf nt child of Mr. and Mrs. John McFadden died Saturday evening and was buried Monday at the home of Mrs. Chas Horsley, at Yellow Gravel. . Mr. Leslie Scruggs, operator at James, on the Norfolk and Western Railway, will shortly move back to old Buckingham to reside with hiB father-in law on Mortevideo farm. Misses Loulie and Fannie HorB- ley, of Travellers Rest, left for Richmond to join their cousin, Mr. Benson Caldwell, who will take them to Charlotte, N. C., on a visit of three weeks. Mr. E. H. Swinley who left nine years ago for the Phillipine Islands has retarned to Travellers Rest,I and will make that his home fori the present. Mr. S. A. Harris, of Lynchburg,! is vititing Mr. and Mrs. Johul Horsley, at Yellow Gravel. He was verv successful in bis hunt, carry ing back twenty birds and six rab bits. Shooting off chickens, pigs, and 1 turkeys seem to be all the go now iu Buckingham. Mr. Province, the Methodist minister has succeeded in building a pretty church near Woodland. We will have services the 4th Sun-j day in February. Mrs. Gibson will soon return to her home near Manteo, greatly ben- efitted by her trip. Her grand daughter who has been living in Kentucky since her marriage will also live there. We are glad to welcome her back. Mrs. A. C. Horsey, of Warmis- I ter, is quite sick with grippe.

document.text: Upholds Hepburn Act. Norfolk.Circuit Judge McLemor in the first case to rise in Virginia under the Hepburn act held the law to be constitutional, and that the shipper could recover from the Initial carrier all losses sustained on con necting railroad lines. The case, which was against the Norfolk and Western Railway in the matter o truck shipments to Chicago, will b appealed to the Supreme Court.

document.text: Twenty contracts totaling 17,556,448 have been approv ed for award by the State Highway and Transportation Commission on the basis of bids received October 13th in Richmond. One of the twenty contracts mentioned above is the construction of a 157-foot-long bridge over the Norfolk and Western Railway tracks on Secondary 647 in Appomattox County. It approaches in the Spout Spring area. Pearson  White Construction, Inc. are contractors for this project. The cost is set at 185,334.

document.text: To endow a scientific and technical school with a fund of 500,090 at Wash ington and Lee University, is the latest suggestion advanced by Mr. Herbert Welsh, of Philadelphia. Mr. Welsh was instrumental In the raising of the Wil son endowment fund of 100,000 for Washington and Lee University, was the fund treasurer and has written Pres ident Denny and expressed great confi dence that such a fund could be raised and promised his cordial assistance it undertaken by the board of trustees and faculty of the university. The Por trait of the late President William L. Wilson, of Washington and Lee uni versity to be unveiled Wednesday, June 18, has been received at tne University. It was executed by Mr. Frank M. Peb bles, and represents Mr. Wilson seated in a chair. The painting is very hand somely executed, and is. three-quarters iife size. It was taken from a portrait made late In his life which hung in his home in Lexington. Mr. Wilson made a provision in his will that it should be painted and given to Washington and Lee University, and it was Mr. Wilsons parting gift to the university he pre sided over so ably. Postmaster Bentley Kern, of Winches ter, received through the mail an un usual request. Out in Oakland, Cal., tiie citizens propose to plant a tree on May 30 in the cemetery there to the memory of the late President McKin ley, and the committee wrote to Post master Kern for earth taken from the battlefield of Winchester, upon which young McKinley, as an officer in__an Ohio regiment, fought during the Civil War, to be used in planting the tree. The Old Dominion soil was forwarded as requested. The largest catch of fish from a single trap ever reported in this section was made a few days ago by a Mr. Hayme, f Recdville. Northumberland county, fsiting in the mouth of the Rappahan nock river, when 2,700 shad were taken from one net at a single haul, and then hundreds of other fish were left. Two or three such hauls in a season would make the fisherman well-to-do in a short time, especially when fish are as high as at present. Another enterprise was launched in Fredericksburg, when the subscribers to the stock of the new shirt factory or ganized by the election of the following officers G. W. Shepherd, president W. D. Carter, vice-president  C. I. Stengle. secretary  A. Randolph Howard, treas urer. The enterprise will be known as the Virginia Shirt Company, and  the plant will be in operation in a very short time. Twenty-seven carpenters of Freder icksburg organized the United Brother hood of Carpenters and Joiners. No. 1078, by the election of J. Mack Latham, president R. L. Heflin, vice-president M. P. McDonald, secretary  A. D. King, treasurer. The object of tile organiza tion is mutual protection, and it is ben eficial in character. The differences between the machinists of the Bluefield. Norfolk and Western Railway shops and the officials of that road have been amicably settled. It is not known just what concessions were made on either side, but it has beer given out that there will be no strike. At Richmond Judge Lamb, of the Richmond Chancery Court, refused tc confirm the offer of io.oco of the Grand Ledge of Elks for the hotel at Bedford City. It was proposed to convert this handsome hostelry into a national home for aged and infirm members of the or der. R. M.. Allen, of Memphis. Tenn., who is wanted in Richmond, Winchester and Washington, D. C , on the chargé of obtaining money under false pretenses and skipping board bills, vas arrested at Front Royal and confined in the coun ty jail to await the arrival of the Win chester authorities. The officers of the Roanoke military companies have received their commis sions, as follows W. W. Hanson, cap tain W. F. Walsh, first lieutenant, and H. L. Francis, second lieutenant of the Roanoke Blues, and S. P. Bruce, second lieutenant of the Roanoke Light Infan try. Norfolk and Baltimore capitalists will erect a six-story hotel at Norfolk, to cost 400,000. The building Vill be devoted exclusively to the entertaining of guests, containing no stores or -offices on the ground floor. The work of construction will begin next month. Four members of the Wright-Tempie- ton gang were captured near Skelton, Tenn., just over the Virginia line. They are known as Winiger, the Byington brothers and Hargrove. The men were taken to Gate City and jailed. Tlie Democrats of Prince William county will hold a meeting May 5 to ex press an opinion whether the new consti tution should be proclaimed or submit ted to the voters. At Danville George Boulden, of Frank lin county, was adjudged guilty of il licit distilling in the United States Court ?nd sentenced to 14 months in the peni tentiary and fined 100. Rc . E. J. Ballou, of Craigsville, has aeclincd a call to the Falling Springs ind Glasgow Presbyterian Churches in Rockbridge county.

document.text: THOMASVILLE PLANS EXPANSION IN BROOKNEAL contd from page 1 of community spirit we like to share.   . Finch said that no timetable has been established ss to when the plant would beginproduc tion, nor has an employment figure been determined. It is expected, he said, that most of the employee force for the new facility would be hired from the Brookneal area and other parts of Campbell County, although some supervisory personnel would probably be transferred from other Thomaaville plants. The plant site is situated just west of Brookneal. It fronts on U. S. Route 501 and is served by the Norfolk and. Western Railway. Thomasville Furniture Indus tries is a maker of high quality bedroom, dining room, and living room furniture sold under the Thomasville, Found ers, and Huntley names. It is based a t Thomasviild, N.C. and is a subsidiary of A rm strong jCork Company, Lancaster, Pa. Armstrong and its associated companies are also leading producers of interior furnishings, including resilient flooring, carpeting, and ceiling systems. H ie parent company also makes a variety of specialty products for the building, textile, automotive, and other industries. The new plant at Brookneal would be the 21st Thomasville Furniture Industries manufact uring facility. All of the other 20 are located in the Southeast-one in Virginia at Appom attox, T8 in. North Carolina, and one in Mississippi .Another Armstrong affiliate, E  B Carpet Mills, Inc., operates a carpet yarn spinning plant at Keysville, Va.

document.text: THOM AS H . IRVING PAM PLIN - Thomas Henry f Irving, 86, of Durham, N. C  j died Tuesday at Watts Hospital I of Durham. Born in Prince Edwprd I County, he was a son of Edward  A . and Rosa Gilliam Irving. He  was a retired brakeman for the Norfolk and Western Railway.  He is survived by a sister, i M rs. Guy Harrison of Hopewell, a sister-in-law, Mrs. Frank M. Irving of Pampiin, and a niece, Mrs. W . D . Crews of Hopewell. Graveside services will be conducted  p. m. Thursday in the Gilliam Family cemetery on the Frank M. Irving farm, R t. 1, Pampiin. The family requests that those wishing to make memor ials consider their favorite charity. document.text: This little old lady inherited railroad stock from her husband. It was worth the cost of one caboose. As everyone knows, one caboose doesnt make a railroad nor does one stockholder comprise its ownership. The Norfolk and Western, for example, is owned by many thousands of people in all walks of life in all parts of the country  folks who have saved their money and invested it in N  W stock. If you wanted to buy the Norfolk and Western, youd have to make your check for many millions of dollars. But you wouldnt send the check to the Norfolk and Western Railway Company, because the Company doesnt own the stock. Instead, youd have to buy it in bits and pieces of stock owned by 31,818 different shareholders  men, women,

document.text: The statement revealed that in October, 5,329 Carloads of revenue freight were loaded on the railroad in a single day..an all-time record, and a 56 per cent increase over the average day of three months before. Five times in a few short weeks, according to the railroad, the, N.  W. was called upon to provide more equipment and service to move coal than ever before in the history of the Norfolk and Western. In Octo- ber, toe N.  W. loaded more coal in one day- 4,255 cars more in one wek-22,706 cars and more in one month- 97,140 cars, than in any like periods- since the railway built into the coal fields 56 years ago. The statement pointed out that this achievement was made poss ible by experienced, loyal personnel, by cooperation of shippers and re-  ceivers, and by the railways poHey of expanding and improving its fac ilities and services in boom times and in depression. Today, the Nor folk and Western is rolling and ready for more- .with plenty of ca pacity in reserve. The railroad asserted that again the Norfolk and Western Railway, and other railroads of the country, have proven conclusively that they ca do the nations transportation job bettor than any other agency- no matter what may come and that they are vital to toe economic pro gress. and welfare of America.

document.text: The proposed project, if ap proved, would begin on its nor thern end where Court Street intersect l itb Considerate Boulevard US 460. Following the existing alignment without any relocation, it would extend in a southeasterly direction 0.6 of a mile to where Court Street intersects with Main Street. If approved, the p r o j e c t would widen Court Street from its present variable widths of from 20 to 30 feet to a uni form 36 - foot width. It would also result in the construction of a 2.5 -foot curb and gutter along each side of the roadway, and a concrete sidewalk. The proposed construction would no cause displacement of any families, individuals or businesses. The estimated daily traffic volume over this segment of road for 1971 was 2,500 ve hicles a day it is projected to be 3,750 by 1991. document.text: The Norfolk and Western Railway and the great territory it serves have forged ahead during the recent lean years. Being a home town railroad, the N.  W. is naturally proud of these records. Since 1930 the railway has authorized the expenditure of more than 66,000,000 for additions and betterments to its transportation plant, and for refinements in its services. This progressive program has kept N.  W. folks at work and spread business along our lines. Our freight service has never been better. We have speeded up schedules. We have inaugurated free collection and delivery service of less-than-carload freight. We have provided the finest air-conditioned passenger equip ment in the land. Each year sees more industries established along the Norfolk and Western, more ferma developed, more businesses opened up. All of those things reflect e progressive spirit, faith in our railroad and our territory. The Norfolk and Western, together with its patrons, its friends, and its territory, rill continue this march of progress as Amarica goes forward. NORFOLK und WESTERN RA ILW A Y

document.text: The eleventh annual reunion of the old Confederates who fought under Col. John S. Mosby was held at Ber- ryville, near which place during the war Mosbys men made many daring exploits. The meeting was presided over by Col. Joseph Bryan, of Rich mond. Hon. Marshall McCormick de livered the address of welcome and a memorial from the pen of Col. John Alexander, of Leesburg, on the death of Chaplain Sidney Ferguson was read. J. William Foster was elected president and H. S. Ashby adjutant. The reunion closed tonight with an entertainment by Polk Miller and his Old South Quartet. At its regular meeting Garland Rodes Camp, Sons of Veterans, of Lynchburg, selected as their sponsor for the coming Confederate reunion Miss Rebecca Martin and as maid of honor Miss Norvie Craighill. both of that city. The Veterans have invited ex-Gov. Francis T. Nichols, who is spending the summer at Chase City, to attend the reunion and be one of the speakers. _ A call was issued by George E. Caskie, chairman of the executive committee of the Virginia Sunday- School Association, for the-State con vention to be held at Lynchburg Oc tober 3 to 5 . A large number of local committees will go to work at once arid arrange for a large attend ance. The last State convention was hqld at Petersburg in March, 1902.   George W. Wilson, of Fancy Hill, Rockbridge county, aged 73 years, is dead. He was a descendant of the Wilsons of Tinkling Springs, Augusta county, and had traveled over the whole of the United States. James Norton, of Medford,_ Mass., has discovered what he claimi to be the richest nickel mine in the United States on the edge of Floyd county, 10 miles south o f ShaWsville, on the Norfolk and Western railway. The lead is said to be large and Mr. Norton has ordered machinery for de veloping the property. The find is- lo cated four miles from the property of the United States Arsenic Mines Com pany, which is being operated by Pittsburg capitalists. The City Engineer, of Roanoke, is sued a building permit to the Norfolk and Western Railway for the erection of a new passenger station in that city at an estimated cost of 99,000. The Roanoke City Council enacted a Pure Food and Milk law. A drastic anti-gambling ordinance just enacted by the Roanoke City Council provides for a fine of not less than 50 nor more than 500 fot gaming. Mayor Cutchin says that he will permit no games of chance at the Roanoke fair in September. Mayor Joel H. Cutchin, of Roanoke, who was recently re-elected, in an in terview said he had given his time, attention and very best efforts to the city for two years and that his poli tical opponents have made the posi tion as unpleasant as possible. The Council, he says, has continually fought him in everything he attempts to do in the interest of the city, and recent proceedings he fears is an in dication that the same tactics will con tinue in the new Council. If so, he cannot and will not stand it. Some whom he thought were. his friends have shown an animosity that does not please him. He says the salary, which is less than any officer, police man or blacksmith of the city, is no compensation for the duties he is called upon to perform, to say nothing of a continual wrangle with the Coun cil, which is annoying to him and humiliating and distasteful to his rela tives and family. The Mayor says that the office has destroyed his law business and the continued harassing has injured his health and peace of mind. He says that if present condi tions continue no gentleman can- or will be Mayor of Roanoke. W. E. Ehoflf, 26 years old, is under arrest at Newport News on the charge of housebreaking, committed nearly six years ago. Ehoff was then living with his parents in Newport News. When he learned that a warrant had been sworn out against him he went to Philadelphia. While living there he was married, and a few days ago reappeared in Newport News with two children. The celebrated suit for divorce of Mrs. Olivia Thurman from her hus band, Gen. Charles Thurman, a rich landowner of Clarke county, which has been before the public frequently during the last year, was settled out of court. A decree will be entered giving Mrs. Thurman a divorce a mens et thoro, which will become absolute in three years, when alimony will cease. Caroline County Camp of Confed erate Veterans has decided to raise 2,500 for the erection of a monument to the Confederate soldiers of that county who were killed or died in the service. Rev. A. C. Knibb. a ministerial stu dent at the Virginia Christian Colege, of Lynchburg, has been conducting a protracted meeting in a tent in West Lynchburg for six weeks and nearly 300 persons have professed conver sion. About 200 persons have been baptized and many others will receive the ordinance-in a day or two. A broken axle wrecked n ears of a freight train on the Atlantic Coast line near Emnoria. No one was hurt. Mrs. R. L. Pownell, of Sherman dis trict. near Romney, was badly scald ed in the face while boiling hops. Miss Elizabeth Booker, of Lynch burg. who was injured in a runaway a- nt, has recovered consciousness after Iving in a comatose condition for more than 75 hours.

document.text: The coffers of Virginias state treasury took on a sizable bulge this  week, when the Common wealths largest single taxpayer, the Norfolk and Western Railway, paid its state taxes for the year, amounting to 1,045,893.62. The check for the huge sum was de livered in person by F. G. McGee, of Roanoke, the companys treas urer, to Governor James H. Price, at his office in Richmond.

document.text: .Spout Spring, Va.- John Wesley Coleman Jr. died at his home here February 2, after a year illness. Born in Charlotte County Sept. 27, 1886, he was the son of the late John W. and Emma Smith Coleman. A retired carpenters foreman for Norfolk and Western Railway, he was the widower of Martha Wool dridge Coleman, who died in 1955. He was a member of Spout Spring Baptist Church and Reedy Springs Masonic Lodge, No. 203, Concord. Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. J. E. Moms, Spout Spring three brothers, Luther Coleman, Lynch burg Andrew Coleman, Appomat tox, and Benjamin Coleman, Staun ton  a sister, Mrs. W. C. Roach, of Phenix, and by three grandchildren Funeral services were conducted at 2 P. M_ Feb. 4, at the Spout Spring Baptist Church, by the pas tor, the Rev. Colin Godwin. Music was provided by the church choir. Active poill bearers were R. O. Rucker, W. M. Roberts, Billy Bryahit, G. M. Rucker, James Ford and C. R. Thompson. Masonic rites were said at th e grave by Reedy Springs Masonic Lodge No. 203, of Concord. Burial was in Liberty Cemetery, Appomattox.
